items.title: Thursday briefing: What the first phase of a Gaza peace plan will bring
items.standfirst: In today‚Äôs newsletter: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas will see the release of hostages and the withdrawal of most of Israel‚Äôs troopsGood morning. After more than two years of devastating war, a ceasefire has finally been announced in Gaza.US president Donald Trump said Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a peace plan to pause fighting and secure the release of hostages and prisoners. Under the deal, Hamas is expected to release 20 surviving hostages over the coming days in exchange for Palestinian detainees, while Israeli forces will begin withdrawing from most of Gaza.Gaza | Israel and Hamas have agreed to the ‚Äúfirst phase‚Äù of a peace plan to pause fighting and release some hostages and prisoners held in Gaza, bringing the best hope yet of a definitive end to a bloody two-year conflict that has killed ten of thousands, destabilised much of the Middle East and prompted protests across the world.Health | Ministers are preparing to raise the amount the NHS pays pharmaceutical firms for medicines by up to 25% after weeks of intensive talks with the Donald Trump administration and drugmakers.Education | Universities in the UK reassured arms companies they would monitor students‚Äô chat groups and social media accounts after firms raised concerns about campus protests, according to internal emails.AI | The Bank of England has warned there is a growing risk of a ‚Äúsudden correction‚Äù in global markets as it raised concerns about soaring valuations of leading AI tech companies.Politics | The Conservatives will scrap stamp duty on sales of primary residences if they win the next election, Kemi Badenoch has said, in a policy-heavy speech designed to improve her standing as Tory leader and her party‚Äôs economic credibility with voters. Continue reading...
items.content: In today‚Äôs newsletter: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas will see the release of hostages and the withdrawal of most of Israel‚Äôs troopsGood morning. After more than two years of devastating war, a ceasefire has finally been announced in Gaza.US president Donald Trump said Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a peace plan to pause fighting and secure the release of hostages and prisoners. Under the deal, Hamas is expected to release 20 surviving hostages over the coming days in exchange for Palestinian detainees, while Israeli forces will begin withdrawing from most of Gaza.Gaza | Israel and Hamas have agreed to the ‚Äúfirst phase‚Äù of a peace plan to pause fighting and release some hostages and prisoners held in Gaza, bringing the best hope yet of a definitive end to a bloody two-year conflict that has killed ten of thousands, destabilised much of the Middle East and prompted protests across the world.Health | Ministers are preparing to raise the amount the NHS pays pharmaceutical firms for medicines by up to 25% after weeks of intensive talks with the Donald Trump administration and drugmakers.Education | Universities in the UK reassured arms companies they would monitor students‚Äô chat groups and social media accounts after firms raised concerns about campus protests, according to internal emails.AI | The Bank of England has warned there is a growing risk of a ‚Äúsudden correction‚Äù in global markets as it raised concerns about soaring valuations of leading AI tech companies.Politics | The Conservatives will scrap stamp duty on sales of primary residences if they win the next election, Kemi Badenoch has said, in a policy-heavy speech designed to improve her standing as Tory leader and her party‚Äôs economic credibility with voters. Continue reading...

items.title: Prisoner-hostage swap, aid surge: What we know about the new Gaza deal
items.standfirst: The first phase of the Gaza peace plan, which is set to be signed Thursday in Egypt, entails the release of 20 living Israeli hostages from Hamas captivity while Israel will release nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners, most of whom were detained at the start of the war, according to sources. Here are more details on the latest US-backed Gaza ceasefire deal.

items.title: Israel and Hamas agree to first phase of peace plan, Trump says
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas have struck a deal for Hamas to release all remaining hostages and for Israel to withdraw its forces to an "agreed upon line," President Trump announced, calling it the "first phase" of a peace deal to end the two-year-long war. Ed O'Keefe and Debora Patta have more.

items.title: Live: Israel, Hamas agreement on Gaza deal expected at noon local time
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a US-proposed Gaza deal, allowing for the release of all Israeli hostages, said President Donald Trump. The agreement, to be signed Thursday at noon local time (11am Paris time), also calls for Israel to release hundreds of Palestinian prisoners as well as prompt a surge of aid into the besieged enclave. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.

Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.

items.title: Outgoing French PM says will present draft budget next Monday
items.standfirst: France's caretaker Prime Minister S√©bastien Lecornu said he'd present a draft bill next Monday, adding that there was "a lot to debate" on the bill. Among the sticking points is President Emmanuel Macron's signature pension reform passed in 2023. So could it possibly be suspended? If so, at what cost? Also in the segment, as the price of gold surges past $4,000/oz, we take a look at the reasons behind the record rally.

items.title: Outgoing French PM says ‚Äòpath still exists‚Äô to avoid snap elections
items.standfirst: S√©bastien Lecornu says majority of MPs willing to seek agreement on budget and avoid further instabilityFrance‚Äôs caretaker prime minister, S√©bastien Lecornu, has said a majority of MPs ‚Äúrejects the idea‚Äù of snap elections and that ‚Äúa path still exists‚Äù that should allow Emmanuel Macron to appoint a new premier within 48 hours.‚ÄúSeveral groups are willing to seek agreement on a budget‚Äù for 2026, Lecornu told France 2 public television on Wednesday, and were making clear their ‚Äúconditions‚Äù. Talks would be difficult, he said, but ‚Äúthe prospect of a dissolution [of parliament] is fading‚Äù. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Outgoing French Prime Minister Lecornu will present a draft budget next Monday.
Lecornu said a majority of MPs reject snap elections and seek budget agreement.
Talks on the budget will be difficult, but dissolution of parliament is fading.
The announcement of a new prime minister follows failed talks by Lecornu.
The sticking points include President Macron's pension reform from 2023.

items.title: Former FBI head James Comey pleads not guilty in Justice Department case pushed by Trump
items.standfirst: Former FBI director James Comey pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to criminal charges accusing him of making false statements to Congress and obstructing a congressional investigation, in the first prosecution by the Justice Departmant against one of US President Donald Trump's political foes. Comey faces up to five years in prison if he is convicted.
items.content: Former FBI director James Comey pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to criminal charges accusing him of making false statements to Congress and obstructing a congressional investigation, in the first prosecution by the Justice Departmant against one of US President Donald Trump's political foes. Comey faces up to five years in prison if he is convicted.

A trial date has been set for January 5.

items.title: The government shutdown might delay your flight
items.standfirst: The only things reliably taking off at airports this week are flight delay times. Travelers are beginning to feel the effects of the ongoing government shutdown as air traffic controllers‚Äîwho are being asked to work without pay‚Äîuse their sick leave instead of coming to work. Staffing shortages‚Ä¶
items.content: The only things reliably taking off at airports this week are flight delay times. Travelers are beginning to feel the effects of the ongoing government shutdown as air traffic controllers‚Äîwho are being asked to work without pay‚Äîuse their sick leave instead of coming to work. Staffing shortages‚Ä¶

items.title: Why the government shutdown is playing into travel delays
items.standfirst: Earlier this week, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said one of the reasons for staffing shortages at airports is that a growing number of air traffic controllers have been calling out sick. Those controllers don't know when they'll get their next paycheck amid the government shutdown. CBS News correspondent Nicole Valdes has more.
items.content: Earlier this week, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said one of the reasons for staffing shortages at airports is that a growing number of air traffic controllers have been calling out sick. Those controllers don't know when they'll get their next paycheck amid the government shutdown. CBS News correspondent Nicole Valdes has more.

ai_summary: Flight delays are increasing due to the government shutdown.
Air traffic controllers are calling out sick due to unpaid work.
Transportation Secretary cited staffing shortages as a factor.

clusters.title: Man charged with starting Palisades fire that killed 12 people
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Charged in Palisades Fire That Killed 12

items.title: Man charged with starting Palisades fire that killed 12 people
items.standfirst: Jonathan Rinderknecht allegedly started blaze that destroyed over 6,800 structures in CaliforniaA 29-year-old man has been arrested and charged with igniting the fire that days later became the devastating Palisades blaze, which killed 12 people and destroyed more than 6,800 structures in one of the most destructive wildfires in Los Angeles history.Jonathan Rinderknecht was arrested near his Florida residence on federal charges of destruction of property by means of fire, acting US attorney for the central district of California, Bill Essayli, announced on Wednesday. No motive was presented. Continue reading...
items.content: Jonathan Rinderknecht allegedly started blaze that destroyed over 6,800 structures in CaliforniaA 29-year-old man has been arrested and charged with igniting the fire that days later became the devastating Palisades blaze, which killed 12 people and destroyed more than 6,800 structures in one of the most destructive wildfires in Los Angeles history.Jonathan Rinderknecht was arrested near his Florida residence on federal charges of destruction of property by means of fire, acting US attorney for the central district of California, Bill Essayli, announced on Wednesday. No motive was presented. Continue reading...

items.title: Man arrested over deadly January fire in Los Angeles
items.standfirst: Authorities investigating the deadly Palisades Fire that tore through an affluent Los Angeles suburb in January said Wednesday they had arrested a man who they believe started the blaze. Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, was taken into custody in Florida, on suspicion of destruction of property by means of fire, Acting United States Attorney Bill Essayli said. FRANCE 24's Wassim Cornet reports from Los Angeles.
items.content: Authorities investigating the deadly Palisades Fire that tore through an affluent Los Angeles suburb in January said Wednesday they had arrested a man who they believe started the blaze. Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, was taken into custody in Florida, on suspicion of destruction of property by means of fire, Acting United States Attorney Bill Essayli said. FRANCE 24's Wassim Cornet reports from Los Angeles.

ai_summary: A man was charged with starting the Palisades fire.
The fire destroyed over 6,800 structures in California.
The suspect was arrested in Florida.

ai_summary: Somalia's President Mohamud supports adopting Swahili.
He believes it is important for regional integration.
The move aims to strengthen ties within the East African Community.
Increased Swahili teaching will boost trade.
The president sees this as crucial for economic growth.
